intro: Cranfillia nukuhivensis, commonly known as the Hiva Island cycad, is a rare and ancient plant species native to the remote Hiva Island in French Polynesia. It belongs to the Cycadaceae family and is characterized by its stout, unbranched trunk and large, pinnate leaves. The plant exhibits a slow growth rate and can live for centuries, making it a symbol of ecological resilience. Due to its limited distribution and habitat threats, it is classified as critically endangered by the IUCN. Its unique botanical features make it a subject of interest for botanists and conservationists alike.
